# Mariana Trench

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about the deep sea trench. For the Canadian band named after
the geological formation, see [Marianas Trench
(band)](/wiki/Marianas_Trench_\(band\) "Marianas Trench \(band\)").

[Coordinates](/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate
system"): [11°21′N 142°12′E﻿ / ﻿11.350°N 142.200°E﻿ / 11.350;
142.200](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mariana_Trench&params=11_21_N_142_12_E_)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Marianatrenchmap.png/290px-
Marianatrenchmap.png)](/wiki/File:Marianatrenchmap.png)

[](/wiki/File:Marianatrenchmap.png "Enlarge")

Location of the Mariana Trench

The **Mariana Trench** or **Marianas Trench**[1] is the
[deepest](/wiki/Deep_sea "Deep sea") part of the world's [oceans](/wiki/Ocean
"Ocean"). It is located in the western [Pacific Ocean](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean
"Pacific Ocean"), an average of 200 kilometres (124 mi) to the east of the
[Mariana Islands](/wiki/Mariana_Islands "Mariana Islands"), in the Western
Pacific east of [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"). It is a
crescent-shaped scar in the Earth's crust, and measures about 2,550 km (1,580
mi) long and 69 km (43 mi) wide on average. It reaches a maximum-known depth
of 10,994 metres (36,070 ft) (± 40 metres [130 ft]) at a small slot-shaped
valley in its floor known as the [Challenger Deep](/wiki/Challenger_Deep
"Challenger Deep"), at its southern end,[2] although some unrepeated
measurements place the deepest portion at 11,034 metres (36,201 ft).[3] For
comparison: if [Mount Everest](/wiki/Mount_Everest "Mount Everest") were
dropped into the trench at this point, its peak would still be over 2
kilometres (1.2 mi) underwater.[a] In 2009, the Marianas Trench was
established as a United States National Monument.[5]

At the bottom of the trench the [water column](/wiki/Water_column "Water
column") above exerts a pressure of 1,086 bars (15,750 psi), more than 1,000
times the [standard atmospheric pressure](/wiki/Standard_atmospheric_pressure
"Standard atmospheric pressure") at sea level. At this pressure, the density
of water is increased by 4.96%, so that 95.27 litres of water under the
pressure of the Challenger Deep would contain the same mass as 100 litres at
the surface. The temperature at the bottom is 1 to 4 °C (34 to 39 °F).[6]

The trench is not the part of the seafloor closest to the [center of the
Earth](/wiki/Earth%27s_center "Earth's center"). This is because the Earth is
not a perfect [sphere](/wiki/Sphere "Sphere"); its radius is about 25
kilometres (16 mi) less at the poles than at the equator.[7] As a result,
parts of the Arctic Ocean seabed are at least 13 kilometres (8.1 mi) closer to
the Earth's center than the Challenger Deep seafloor.

[Xenophyophores](/wiki/Xenophyophore "Xenophyophore") have been found in the
trench by [Scripps Institution of
Oceanography](/wiki/Scripps_Institution_of_Oceanography "Scripps Institution
of Oceanography") researchers at a record depth of 10.6 kilometres (6.6 mi)
below the sea surface.[8] On 17 March 2013, researchers from the [Scottish
Association for Marine Science](/wiki/Scottish_Association_for_Marine_Science
"Scottish Association for Marine Science") reported data that suggested
[microbial life forms](/wiki/Microbes "Microbes") thrive within the
trench.[9][10]

## Names[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mariana_Trench&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Names")]

The Mariana Trench is named for the nearby [Mariana
Islands](/wiki/Mariana_Islands "Mariana Islands") (in turn named Las Marianas
in honor of Spanish Queen [Mariana of Austria](/wiki/Mariana_of_Austria
"Mariana of Austria"), widow of [Philip IV of Spain](/wiki/Philip_IV_of_Spain
"Philip IV of Spain")). The islands are part of the [island
arc](/wiki/Island_arc "Island arc") that is formed on an over-riding plate,
called the Mariana Plate (also named for the islands), on the western side of
the trench.

## Geology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mariana_Trench&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Geology")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Cross_section_of_mariana_trench.svg/350px-
Cross_section_of_mariana_trench.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Cross_section_of_mariana_trench.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Cross_section_of_mariana_trench.svg "Enlarge")

The Pacific plate is subducted beneath the Mariana Plate, creating the Mariana
trench, and (further on) the arc of the Mariana islands, as water trapped in
the plate is released and explodes upward to form island volcanoes and
earthquakes .

The Mariana Trench is part of the [Izu-Bonin-Mariana](/wiki/Izu-Bonin-
Mariana_Arc "Izu-Bonin-Mariana Arc") [subduction](/wiki/Subduction
"Subduction") system that forms the [boundary](/wiki/Convergent_boundary
"Convergent boundary") between two [tectonic plates](/wiki/Tectonic_plate
"Tectonic plate"). In this system, the western edge of one plate, the [Pacific
Plate](/wiki/Pacific_Plate "Pacific Plate"), is [subducted](/wiki/Subduction
"Subduction") (i.e., thrust) beneath the smaller [Mariana
Plate](/wiki/Mariana_Plate "Mariana Plate") that lies to the west. Crustal
material at the western edge of the Pacific Plate is some of the oldest
oceanic crust on earth (up to 170 million years old), and is therefore cooler
and more dense; hence its great height difference relative to the higher-
riding (and younger) Mariana Plate. The deepest area at the plate boundary is
the Mariana Trench proper.

The movement of the Pacific and Mariana plates is also indirectly responsible
for the formation of the [Mariana Islands](/wiki/Mariana_Islands "Mariana
Islands"). These volcanic islands are caused by [Flux
melting](/wiki/Flux_melting "Flux melting") of the upper mantle due to release
of water that is trapped in minerals of the subducted portion of the Pacific
Plate.

## Measurements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mariana_Trench&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Measurements")]

See also: [Challenger Deep](/wiki/Challenger_Deep "Challenger Deep")

The trench was first [sounded](/wiki/Depth_sounding "Depth sounding") during
the [_Challenger_ expedition](/wiki/Challenger_expedition "Challenger
expedition") in 1875, using a weighted rope, which recorded a depth of 4,475
[fathoms](/wiki/Fathom "Fathom") (8,184 metres; 26,850 feet).[11] In 1877, a
map was published called _Tiefenkarte des Grossen Ozeans_ ("Deep map of the
Great Ocean") by Petermann, which showed a _Challenger Tief_ ("Challenger
deep") at the location of that sounding. In 1899, [USS
Nero](/wiki/USS_Nero_\(AC-17\) "USS Nero \(AC-17\)"), a converted collier,
recorded a depth of 5,269 fathoms (9,636 metres; 31,614 feet).[12]

In 1951, _[Challenger II](/wiki/HMS_Challenger_\(1931\) "HMS Challenger
\(1931\)")_ surveyed the trench using [echo sounding](/wiki/Echo_sounding
"Echo sounding"), a much more precise and vastly easier way to measure depth
than the sounding equipment and drag lines used in the original expedition.
During this survey, the deepest part of the trench was recorded when the
_Challenger II_ measured a depth of 5,960 fathoms (10,900 metres; 35,760 feet)
at [11°19′N 142°15′E﻿ / ﻿11.317°N 142.250°E﻿ / 11.317;
142.250](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mariana_Trench&params=11_19_N_142_15_E_),
known as the [Challenger Deep](/wiki/Challenger_Deep "Challenger Deep").[13]

In 1957, the [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") vessel
[_Vityaz_](/wiki/RV_Vityaz_\(1939\) "RV Vityaz \(1939\)") reported a depth of
11,034 metres (36,201 ft) at a location dubbed the _Mariana Hollow_.[3]

In 1962, the surface ship M.V. _Spencer F. Baird_ recorded a maximum depth of
10,915 metres (35,810 ft) using precision depth gauges.

In 1984, the Japanese survey vessel _Takuyō_ (拓洋) collected data from the
Mariana Trench using a narrow, multi-beam echo sounder; it reported a maximum
depth of 10,924 metres (35,840 ft), also reported as 10,920 metres (35,830 ft)
±10 m (33 ft).[14] Remotely Operated Vehicle _[KAIKO](/wiki/Kaik%C5%8D
"Kaikō")_ reached the deepest area of the Mariana Trench and made the deepest
diving record of 10,911 metres (35,797 ft) on March 24, 1995.[15]

During surveys carried out between 1997 and 2001, a spot was found along the
Mariana Trench that had depth similar to that of the Challenger Deep, possibly
even deeper. It was discovered while scientists from the [Hawaii Institute of
Geophysics and Planetology](/wiki/University_of_Hawaii "University of Hawaii")
were completing a survey around [Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam"); they used a sonar
mapping system towed behind the research ship to conduct the survey. This new
spot was named the [HMRG (Hawaii Mapping Research Group) Deep](/wiki/HMRG_Deep
"HMRG Deep"), after the group of scientists who discovered it.[16]

On 1 June 2009, sonar mapping of the Challenger Deep by the Simrad EM120 sonar
multibeam bathymetry system for deep water, mapping aboard the _[RV Kilo
Moana](/wiki/RV_Kilo_Moana "RV Kilo Moana")_ (mothership of the Nereus
vehicle), indicated a spot with a depth of 10,971 metres (35,994 ft). The
sonar system uses phase and amplitude bottom detection, with an accuracy of
better than 0.2% of water depth across the entire swath (implying that the
depth figure is accurate to ± 22 metres (72 ft)).[17][18]

In 2011, it was announced at the [American Geophysical
Union](/wiki/American_Geophysical_Union "American Geophysical Union") Fall
Meeting that a US Navy hydrographic ship equipped with a [multibeam
echosounder](/wiki/Multibeam_echosounder "Multibeam echosounder") conducted a
survey which mapped the entire trench to 100 metres (330 ft) resolution.[2]
The mapping revealed the existence of four rocky outcrops thought to be former
[seamounts](/wiki/Seamount "Seamount").[19]

The Mariana Trench is a site chosen by researchers at [Washington
University](/wiki/Washington_University "Washington University") and the
[Woods Hole Oceanographic
Institution](/wiki/Woods_Hole_Oceanographic_Institution "Woods Hole
Oceanographic Institution") in 2012 for a seismic survey to investigate the
subsurface [water cycle](/wiki/Water_cycle "Water cycle"). Using both [ocean-
bottom seismometers](/wiki/Ocean-bottom_seismometer "Ocean-bottom
seismometer") and [hydrophones](/wiki/Hydrophone "Hydrophone") the scientists
are able to map structures as deep as 97 kilometres (60 mi) beneath the
surface.[20]

### Descents[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mariana_Trench&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Descents")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Bathyscaphe_Trieste.jpg/220px-
Bathyscaphe_Trieste.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bathyscaphe_Trieste.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bathyscaphe_Trieste.jpg "Enlarge")

The [bathyscaphe](/wiki/Bathyscaphe "Bathyscaphe")
_[Trieste](/wiki/Bathyscaphe_Trieste "Bathyscaphe Trieste")_ (designed by
[Auguste Piccard](/wiki/Auguste_Piccard "Auguste Piccard")), the first manned
vehicle to reach the bottom of the Mariana Trench.[21]

Four descents have been achieved. The first was the manned descent by Swiss-
designed, Italian-built, [United States Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United
States Navy")-owned [bathyscaphe](/wiki/Bathyscaphe "Bathyscaphe")
_[Trieste](/wiki/Bathyscaphe_Trieste "Bathyscaphe Trieste")_ which reached the
bottom at 1:06 pm on 23 January 1960, with [Don Walsh](/wiki/Don_Walsh "Don
Walsh") and [Jacques Piccard](/wiki/Jacques_Piccard "Jacques Piccard") on
board.[13][22] Iron shot was used for [ballast](/wiki/Sailing_ballast "Sailing
ballast"), with gasoline for [buoyancy](/wiki/Buoyancy "Buoyancy").[13] The
onboard systems indicated a depth of 11,521 m (37,799 ft), but this was later
revised to 10,916 m (35,814 ft).[23] The depth was estimated from a conversion
of [pressure](/wiki/Pressure "Pressure") measured and calculations based on
the [water density](/wiki/Density_of_saltwater "Density of saltwater") from
sea surface to seabed.[22]

This was followed by the unmanned
[ROVs](/wiki/Remotely_operated_underwater_vehicle "Remotely operated
underwater vehicle") _[Kaikō](/wiki/Kaik%C5%8D "Kaikō")_ in 1996 and
[_Nereus_](/wiki/Nereus_\(underwater_vehicle\) "Nereus \(underwater
vehicle\)") in 2009. The first three expeditions directly measured very
similar depths of 10,902 to 10,916 m (35,768 to 35,814 ft). The fourth was
made by Canadian film director [James Cameron](/wiki/James_Cameron "James
Cameron") in 2012. On 26 March, he reached the bottom of the Mariana Trench in
the submersible vessel _[Deepsea Challenger](/wiki/Deepsea_Challenger "Deepsea
Challenger")_.[24][25][26]

In July 2015, members of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration,
Oregon State University, and the Coast Guard submerged a hydrophone into the
deepest part of the Mariana Trench, the Challenger Deep, never having deployed
one past a mile. The titanium-shelled hydrophone was designed to withstand the
immense pressure 7 miles under.[27] Although researchers were unable to
retrieve the hydrophone until November, the data capacity was full within the
first 23 days. After months of analyzing the sounds, the experts were
surprised to pick up natural _and_ man-made sounds such as boats, earthquakes,
a typhoon, and baleen whales.[28] Due to the mission's success, the
researchers announced plans to deploy a second hydrophone in 2017 for an
extended period of time.

### Planned
descents[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mariana_Trench&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Planned descents")]

![Ambox current
red.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ambox_current_red.svg/42px-
Ambox_current_red.svg.png)| This section needs to be **updated**. Please
update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.
_(May 2018)_  
---|---  
  
As of February
2012[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mariana_Trench&action=edit),
at least two other teams are planning piloted submarines to reach the bottom
of the Mariana Trench. Triton Submarines, a Florida-based company that designs
and manufactures private submarines, plans for a crew of three to take 120
minutes to reach the seabed.[29] [DOER Marine](/wiki/DOER_Marine "DOER
Marine"), a marine technology company based near [San
Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco") and set up in 1992, plans for
a crew of two or three to take 90 minutes to reach the seabed.[30]

## Life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mariana_Trench&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Life")]

The expedition conducted in 1960 claimed to have observed, with great surprise
because of the high pressure, large creatures living at the bottom, such as a
[flatfish](/wiki/Flatfish "Flatfish") about 30 cm (12 in) long,[23] and
[shrimp](/wiki/Shrimp "Shrimp").[31] According to Piccard, "The bottom
appeared light and clear, a waste of firm [diatomaceous](/wiki/Diatom
"Diatom") ooze".[23] Many marine biologists are now skeptical of the supposed
sighting of the flatfish, and it is suggested that the creature may instead
have been a [sea cucumber](/wiki/Sea_cucumber "Sea cucumber").[32][33] During
the second expedition, the unmanned vehicle Kaikō collected mud samples from
the [seabed](/wiki/Seabed "Seabed").[34] Tiny organisms were found to be
living in those samples.

In July 2011, a research expedition deployed untethered landers, called
dropcams, equipped with digital video and lights to explore this region of the
deep sea. Amongst many other living organisms, some gigantic single-celled
amoebas with a size of more than 10 cm (4 in), belonging to the class of
[xenophyophores](/wiki/Xenophyophore "Xenophyophore") were observed.[35]
Xenophyophores are noteworthy for their size, their extreme abundance on the
seafloor and their role as hosts for a variety of organisms.

In December 2014, a new species of [snailfish](/wiki/Snailfish "Snailfish")
was discovered at a depth of 8,145 m (26,722 ft), breaking the previous record
for the deepest living fish seen on video.[36]

During the 2014 expedition, several new species were filmed including huge
[crustaceans](/wiki/Crustaceans "Crustaceans") known as supergiants. [Deep-sea
gigantism](/wiki/Deep-sea_gigantism "Deep-sea gigantism") is the process where
species grow larger than their shallow water relatives.[36]

In May 2017 an unidentified type of snailfish was filmed at a depth of 8,178
metres (26,800 ft).[37]

### Pollution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mariana_Trench&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Pollution")]

In 2016, a research expedition looked at the chemical makeup of crustacean
scavengers collected from a range of 7,841–10,250 metres within the trench.
Within these organisms, the researchers found extremely elevated
concentrations of [PCBs](/wiki/Polychlorinated_biphenyl "Polychlorinated
biphenyl"), a chemical toxin banned for its environmental harm in the 1970s,
concentrated at all depths within the sediment of the trench.[38]

## Possible nuclear waste disposal
site[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mariana_Trench&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Possible nuclear waste disposal site")]

Like other oceanic trenches, the Mariana Trench has been proposed as a site
for [nuclear waste](/wiki/Radioactive_waste "Radioactive waste")
disposal,[39][40] in the hope that tectonic plate
[subduction](/wiki/Subduction "Subduction") occurring at the site might
eventually push the nuclear waste deep into the [Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth")'s
[mantle](/wiki/Mantle_\(geology\) "Mantle \(geology\)"), the second layer of
the [Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth"). However, ocean dumping of nuclear waste is
prohibited by international law.[39][40][41] Furthermore, plate subduction
zones are associated with very large [megathrust
earthquakes](/wiki/Megathrust_earthquake "Megathrust earthquake"), the effects
of which are unpredictable for the safety of long-term disposal of nuclear
wastes within the [hadopelagic](/wiki/Hadopelagic "Hadopelagic")
[ecosystem](/wiki/Ecosystem "Ecosystem").[40]

## See also[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mariana_Trench&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: See also")]

  * [![icon](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/%E5%A4%A7%E6%B4%8B.png/32px-%E5%A4%A7%E6%B4%8B.png)](/wiki/File:%E5%A4%A7%E6%B4%8B.png)[Oceania portal](/wiki/Portal:Oceania "Portal:Oceania")

  * [Marianas Trench Marine National Monument](/wiki/Marianas_Trench_Marine_National_Monument "Marianas Trench Marine National Monument"), United States national monument at the trench. This National Monument protects 95,216 square miles (246,610 km2) of submerged lands and waters of the Mariana Archipelago. It includes some of the Mariana Trench, but not the deepest part, the [Challenger Deep](/wiki/Challenger_Deep "Challenger Deep"), which lies just outside the monument area.

section: Notes")]
